reviewText:
I must say that, it's a good game if you simply wanna kill some time now and then when you're downloading sth or 30 minutes away from an appointment. But if you really wann play this game like a professional, you better get ready to empty your purse on fancy cards.

I think most people who played for more than 10 hours would agree that it's simply not possible to just win a game (God, I mean even just a normal duel!) with poor cards and awesome strategies. YOU  MUST HAVE AWESOME CARDS!! And i'm afraid all the awesome cards must be bought with real money if you don't want to spend your llife time in this game and earn those in-game currencies.It's still a lota fun when you play with someone on about the same (card) level and who enjoys simple duels, but I'm afraid that doesn't happen too often when you level up or getting to higher than 500 ELO, which is in most cases as far as you can get without buying cards with cash.

It's a good game, if you have a good temper AND a lot of patience AND always accept your failures because other people simply spend more money but not more brain than you. I would say that this game has a lot of potential (a very good duel system afterall, except for the tournament part), if it's not designed to devour your savings that deliberately and hungrily, it'll definitely do better.

reviewText:
TL; DR: Quite playable and enjoyable, if you like collectible card games. Try it out, but only spend money if you're actually hooked by the gameplay.

The game sports an interesing lane system for creature attacks. Redeployment can be just as (if not more) important than attacking. The two rows allow for tactical positioning if you built your deck right.

The game consists of a 'campaign' component that pits your decks against quite a few computer-controlled opponents and their specific decks. They usually build up on a theme and thus become a kind of puzzle to be solved, partially in the deckbuilding and partially in actual play. There are also actual 'puzzles', i.e single-turn 'chess puzzles' that require you to find the right moves to win.

There is a story to the campaign I think, but not anything that seems worth following or remembering. It can be safely ignored.

The second component is the actual game, i.e. the different 1v1 game modes (against other players).

The game sports a considerable number of achievements that award you with different in-game items when first achieved.

Regarding monetization: There are, as is usually the case for such F2P games, two types of currency available: The one you can earn with play and the one you have to buy with actual money. Card packs for the recent expansions are available with the earnable currency. However there is also the option of buying 'premium' packs, which consist of more rare cards than the regular packs.

Balancing: Probably too early to tell, but I have so far found it to be mostly fair. I have only earned currency and cards through play so far and have fared pretty well,but I am not far into the game yet. I seem to win most of my matches against other players, but they will probably be on a similar level to me.

Since it costs nothing but time to first try out I feel confident to recommend the game: If you're unhappy with the gameplay, you can stop without having wasted too much. I would definitely recommend against investing any money into it early. See if you like it, play for a few weeks, then consider whether you want to inject any actual money into it.

reviewText:
My experience as a freebie gamer is mixed. On one hand, i feel rather helpless that knowing that once i had certain cards, i will be much more powerful, but u have to pay real money to buy packs and try ur luck, the other slower but free way is to log in everyday to get free gold/stuff and wildcards, eventually when u accumulated enough wildcards, u can get whatever card u want, but that could take several months.

If i compare this to my favourite CCG, Shadow Era, this game still pales in comparison to diversity in tactics, adding to the fact that in Shadow Era, u can get any individual card u want because u can buy it directly with ingame-earned gold, instead of buying packs.

However, the plus side of Duel Of Champions, is the strategic element of positioning, lacking in many CCGs. Another awesome feature about this game are the Scenario Puzzles, last i know, you have to unlock them 1 by 1 with single player campaign though. To me, the puzzles are very good and test your problem-solving abilities. The puzzle will give you a preset scenario, preset cards, and give u only 1 turn against overwhelming odds, to survive and defeat your AI opponent, like you only have 1 life and opponent has 15 life, and you have to kill your opponent within 1 turn, YOUR TURN. It's possible, through several steps, the solution is usually not immediately obvious, and you have to try out different methods. You will feel smart when you manage to do that on your own without searching for hints.

So, my conclusion,
If Shadow Era is 9/10 (extremely diverse and encourages creativity, totally free to play)
then Duel Of Champions is 7/10 (need effort or money to buy your dream deck)
and HearthStone is 6/10 (too simple and too many limitations for my liking)

But it's worth a try, you may like it.

reviewText:
This game had some great potential to be a good trading card game. Sadly it was ruined by very greedy design choices.

With the Base Set 2 expansion that was released in April 2014 we were told the game will be more free to play". Instead all of the legacy packs (=currently more than 80% of the content) is now only available with seals (= the game's hard currency).

Before the BS2 patch seals were given out every level and with some achievements. After the patch there is no way at all to get seals
date: making most content of the game only available for real money
recommended: thus being much less free to play than any other trading card game out there.\n\nThe steam userbase of this game has gone from 3000-4000 users in November 2013 to 400-500 in May 2014
hoursPlayed: proving how bad these changes were on the game.\n\nAvoid this game! Play Hearthstone
voteText: Infinity Wars or HexTCG (still in beta) instead."

reviewText:
It used to be a great game, and it's still a good game, but only for those who have played lots of hours at the beginning.

Now, you have to put your own (real) money if you want good cards, because if you haven't got seals, you can't get to the good cards or good packs. Now, you can win lots of gold and cards playing the campaign, but this gold is useless, and the little amount of cards you will win can do a little to improve your deck.

Every update makes me to like less this game, and sometimes I ask to myself why I'm still playing it. That's why I can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
Hey ho! This is crazy, DoC arrived to steam.
Excellent strategic card game!
If you want to start the game with 6 decks follow my link at the end of the review.

My steam playtime is not representative at all, add 120h -raptr said so- since the anniversary of the game and third expansion (september 2013). And hundreds during beta in 2012. You can play for free as me with some good decks at level 25 or one good one sooner.

WHAT'S ALL ABOUT?
The core of the game is duels with decks consisting on creatures you deploy on a battlefield to attack the rival and use of spells, fortunes and events to affect rival, creatures, part of the battlefield or the whole battlefield. All in all magic the gathering with a battlefield as you can see on the pictures. Strategically is far supperior to the new wow spin-off copying the battlefield idea. Which in fact existed already on other japanesse game which I forgot the game, yuggi oh maybe?

GAMEPLAY
Deck editor is not perfect but after the improvements it's much more usable and also the card package opening is cute, will make you feel as a kid opening a gift, it also marks the cards you don't have.

You fight other users or vs stupid IA during the campaign to learn the basics and get game currency. Note stupid IA doing wrong moves with good deck and advantage can defeat a noob user.

They implemented tournaments and installed the game into the e-sports world, the problem is that ubi is noob on this and have done some mistakes until now. They're improving, hope the devs get more investment from ubi and the game becomes as good as the potential it showed since the first beta. New cards expansion every four or six months (not remember now) will keep bringing new mechanichs and will make better the game. Also the spectator mode will come and they help everyone doing clan tournaments.

At this point of reading you should be convinced to download it and give it a go. It's free and you start with a basic deck and some card packages so you can taste the deck editor. Matchmaking will pair you with people that has your gaming level (not profile level) except in tournaments.

PROMO CODES SYSTEM IS BACK ON STEAM CLIENT TOO
You can register through my referral[signup.duelofchampions.com], so you start with 6 decks and I will get a little part of what you earn/spend.
If you want codes that provide extra cards, just ask me and I will gladly tell you the still active ones.
Specially I think I have one or two codes that work only during the first 6 hours of registration so if you plan to start this game ask me BEFORE registering, to planify and get them. The previous promos ran out of keys:

grab a code here to get 120 cards (accounts with less than 6 hours)": old promos[eu.alienwarearena.com]

BUYING ON STEAM THE DLCs OR INSIDE THE SHOP?
Don't get the expensive dlcs
date: probably is better to spend money on the internal store so you get seals you can distribute as you wish. To maximize the impact of themoney buy seals when the company gift booster packs as reward
recommended: and spend the seals when there is a promo on the store."

reviewText:
After having spent 200 Euros (about 300 Dollars (!)) and 250 hours of play (Steam and Steamless), all i can say is:

DONT ... START... PLAYING... THIS... GAME!!!

I had chosen DOC because i thought the financing model was generous. But how wrong i was.
You do earn ingame currency fast and are able to buy boosters often, indeed.

The problem, however, is, that you wont ever get all the cards you need to play competitive, without spending very, very much money.
There are lots of players which leave tons a cash here, and they will beat your ♥♥♥ over and over again!
So, in order to compete, you WILL get to the point, where you have to spend real money or quit. And if you choose to stay, and most likely you will, because its a very funny game and nobody wants to surrender, you're doomed. People who know Magic the Gathering will know what im talking about, with the only difference, that DOC does NOT support trading.

You will have to achieve your cards by drawing!
And epic cards are VERY hard to get.

I still am feeling bad every day for having paid so freaking much money for nothing, couldnt even compete with the good players, and dont get a single penny back.

Do yourself a favour and !dont! play this game...

reviewText:
Arguably, one of the most innovative Collectible Card Game around. Unlike many of its competitors, the available space on the battlefield is limited to a 4x4 grid split in half between you and your opponent: the key to victory lies in the correct positioning and movement of your own creatures, and it is often possible to defeat the enemy hero while his creatures are  still on board.

Creatures and heroes are related to one of the factions available, which is six as of the expansion Griffin Bane; there are also some neutral creatures that can be used by any hero, but they have either very specific uses, or are meant to be used as filler until you earn better creatures of a certain faction. Still, once you have unlocked heroes of other factions, expect to fight and use a wide variety of cards; just like any other card game, it's up to you to discover what's userful and what is not for your decks.

The economic model has been the cause of many controversies in the past, but after much twiddling Ubisoft has finally managed to create a system that works for them and for us both. There are  two  three currencies available: you earn Gold as you play (even more if you actually manage to win), and you spend it to buy packs for the Standard format (the newest and the most relatively balanced, it is composed of Base Set 2, Heart of Nightmares and Griffin Bane).

Seals, on the other hand, are a premium currency mostly available through real money. Seals can buy you anything from any previous set, and hasten up the creations of decks immensely by giving you Wildcards. The Open format allows you to play with any cards you have, just don't expect it to be balanced in the slightest.

Apart from achievements or seals-bought packs, you'll start earning Wildcards by completing daily quests once you reach Champion I level. If you don't like the quest, simply forfeit it to recieve another one. You can exchange Wildcards to get specific cards in the Altar of Wishes. This is the most reliable way to get rare cards.

Achievements and daily quests will earn you quite a lot of gold, but the first thing you should aim to complete is the PvE campaign. It is very generous with the rewards, and every mission can be completed once again with each faction for the same reward.

Additionally, you will want to insert these codes in the ingame shop to earn some free goodies. Just go to the shop and click on the Redeem Code button.

CD-Action-Play-MMDoC (2 BS2 packs)
TH4NK5-70K-D0C-F4CEB00K-L3G1ON (2 HoN premium packs)

Lastly, you can use my referral link to get six heroes of all different factions.
https://signup.duelofchampions.com/portal/index/DOC_world_02_0010_06_200_12_0614_00♥♥♥♥♥♥♥LUILUH

reviewText:
MMDoC is one of my favorite games.  I DLed it while waiting for a Hearthstone beta key, turns out there was no contest for me between the two.
An underrated game with amazing art, solid balance, fun tactics, diverse deck compositions and specifications.  There are a few bugs you might encounter from time to time, but nothing severe.
It will take either money or time to build a solid deck, but it does give you a goal to work for and time to learn the game. There is nothing pay to win here as nothing is out of reach with a purely free-to-play account.
Unfortunately, the game has officially lost support and won't be recieving new updates after tomorrow (10/14/2015).

reviewText:
Duel Of Champions is an pvp card game that features Creatures, Spells and Fortunes.

Flaws of the game:
It sometimes freezes when you start a duel.
You can be thrown agianst a player with like 500+ more elo than you. (i dont mind, bring it!)
People can elo drop from the +1001 if they like to keep bashing noobs.
You cannot trade cards with your friends.

Epic parts of the game:
You can trade in cards to get gold back from cards that you dont need.
Every time you buy new card packs you get wild cards" witch lets you get the that one card you are looking for.
No level cap (as far as i know).
Daily rewards. (witch you can stack up 7 times to get seal = pay to win gold ingame)
Achivements that lets you go for hilarious decks to win with.
Missions to help you get some new cards fast when your new to the game. (not that many yet but they say they will add more to the game)
6 Different races + 1 everyone can use.
648'ish cards to choose from. (and more comming soon)
Good tutorial to help new players."

reviewText: While it is free to play, if your not looking to dump $$$, this game might not be for you.  It is extremely fun and engaging and there are ways to earn the in game currency (gold and seals) without spending money.  The problem comes later on, when you have to duel other players who have dropped money into the game.  The matches are one sided, to say the least, and it becomes clear that you've reached a fork in the path.  Do you spend the money or stop playing.  I will say that the prices are comparable with what RL cards go for.  To get the cheapest booster pack will run $5 and that gets you 2 12 card packs.  All in all its a great game and because it's free-to-play why the hell not just try it out.

reviewText:
Might and Magic is a fun game, it has quite some depth into it, you need good strategies and luck
BUT i cannot recommend this game, invite friends for balanced and fair duels
....a lot cashers are ingame, in ranked and tournaments
which breaks the balance in game

Everyone start with a starting deck
Haven = easy to master, specialize in healing (almost every monster is a tank, high hp , low attack
Inferno = intermediate, specialize in power (almost every monster is a glass cannon, high power , low hp)
Necropolis = intermediate, specialize in ailments (almost every monster is balanced , no pros or cons)
Stronghold = hard , specialize in enragement (almost every monster is balanced to good stats)

when you start you have to choose a deck and complete the tutorial
after that you are launched into the game (after creating a uplay account)
then you can start earning achievements to earn prices , like completing campaign mode
which is good to improve your abilities
but once campaign is finished you have some packs unlocked and get some free card
BE WARNED...every pack gives RANDOM cards
you can unlock wildcards , with enough wildcards you can unlock special monsters or heroes
but the real power of the game lies in the store
you can buy decks , packs etc.
with these you can create ultimate decks... but then again you need to spend money
NOTE: you can earn cash money ingame , by completing campaign and unlocking achievements
every fight you win , you earn ingame money , some packs you can buy with real money , some only with ingame money
its a fight between time and money , you can cash your way through to become a strong player directly OR you use a lot of your time to duel and kill time
THEN AGAIN if you manage to win of course

the beginning is very easy , because you have a rank
at the beginning your rank is 1 or 0 , and if you sucessfully won a fight , you get +31 points (for example)
the more duels you win , the higher your rank , the higher your rank , the harder duels will become
getting into duels is very fast and fun , just press a button and you are launced into the battle
the playerbase is BIG so its a + the community is very ok , not like in moba games
the only downside is that the duels can DRAG... if the opponent use their sweet time , then you can wait like 3 minutes until its your turn

campaign , duels .... then there is tournament mode.... yeah... have fun winning those !
i did win 1 fight by default (opponent did surrender) but its hardly playable UNLESS you did cash to get very good cards)

and then there is training mode , its just fighting against the AI OR a friend , no rewards its training

and thats all that the game , all you can do is customize your deck , and duel
the campaign isn't worth much , duels can be very fun or very frustrating
tournaments are only for PRO players or cashers , newbies with starter decks doesn't stand a chance

So with that said
I ONLY RECOMMEND PLAYING THIS WITH FRIENDS
try dueling each other  for more points and achievements
its a long grind , but in the end you will come across very good cards
playing alone can be fun too, but the grind is much harder

Final note: i would say give it a try, if you have a LOT of free time and you love card games like yu-gi-oh or magic the gathering , then you enjoy the game, try inviting friends to make the grind easier and become very good
(if you are very impatient and you have a hard time creating a good deck...or don't like stategy games.. don't play this)

Enjoy the game !

reviewText:
This game has a lot going for it. There are a ton of cards with many, many interesting mechanics and abilities. The typical cardgame gameplay is mixed up with the positioning on the board which makes for a cool twist as does the event system. The artwork is good, in parts even spectacular.

Sadly there is so much bad to outweigh the good.

Since this is a F2P game it has of course a daily login bonus, some daily quests and the option to buy additional cards for money. Those are a given in this day and age and I willingly put up with it since the game itself looks so promising. But the developers decided to make only the most recent of the editions buyable for the ingame currency. So a good portion of the cards is out of reach for all free players. Sure, you get the occasional booster for an achievement but thanks to the randomness of those boosters that's not enough to build a solid cardpool.
There are two additional ways to gain cards one might otherwise not see. The Infernal Pit where you sacrifice unneeded cards and the Wildcard mechanic. Both are pretty awesome but again not enough to mitigate the disadvantage one automatically gets for not paying.
In my opinion, a paying player should get his cards at a faster rate, of course, but almost every F2P game goes way overboard with this idea. As a result this bleeds the free player portion away relatively fast and soon there are only some paying dudes left which is not a healthy playerbase.

Then there is the lacking Steam support. MMDOC is a game by Ubisoft and thus requires the player to have an account in their uPlay system. This was annoying enough by itself. But now for some reason they did not update the Steam achievements when they overhauled the whole system ingame. As a result I have some achievements ingame that are not available in Steam whilst I'm missing some on Steam that are not even existant anymore in MMDOC.
This reeks of either incompetence or a disregard for a polished product. Or both.

Since I finished every singleplayer activity I have nothing else to do but to play against other players. Which wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for a couple of issues.

1) The balancing is bad. 3 or 4 out of five games my opponent will play Necropolis. Since this is only one of six factions that's a pretty telling sign. It is also the one faction I (and maybe many others) don't want to play against. It has more annoying mechanics than the other five factions combined. At a high level of gameplay where everybody and their mom has an optimized deck Necropolis might not even be overpowered. But at the low-medium end it is just not fun to play against.
As a general rule of thumb, if you build a deck and include only the most unpleasant cards you possess, chances are you built the strongest deck you can. I'm not talking raw power here. Rather mechanics that are the equivalent to giving your opponent the bird. Necropolis cards are only the most obvious example but it applies to the rest, too.

2) The playerbase is divided into several ranks which reflect your skill and the effectiveness of your decks. When you win a certain number of times you rank up. The only way to avoid this is to lose games. If you don't want to rank up and are about to win, you have to forfeit your game. Once you reached a higher rank there is no way to decrease it. I am now sitting at rank 5 or so (Lord Commander) and have no way of going back. Since I reached Lord Commander my percentage of wins has decreased significantly. Before it was at ~50% which is where it should be if I and my opponents are evenly matched. Now it is way, way below 50%. So it takes me forever to finish my daily quests. And I can't do anything about it. Yeah, that's fun!

I spent a lot of time playing MMDOC and at the beginning it was a pretty good ride. The longer I play it though the more it becomes upsetting. Thanks to my achilles heel (achievements) I'll stay on it for a while longer but I don't expect much happiness to come from this.

reviewText:
I haven't played a this game lot and not enough to make a review about the game itself. But i can review the game mechanics a bit from the standpoint of a CCG (Collectible Card Game).

Loss of game complexity for the sake gameplay simplicity and shorter learning rate was never a good concept for CCG in my opinion. games like this one should be more complex. they are all quite the same even if a few mechanics are different from the rest.
I like CCG and think virtual CCGs are great game genre for a fair progression based system, but most importantly the game needs trading. Else its almost for sure a pay to win title, because there would be no other solution for the publisher to make some cash other then to sell cards or fancy cosmetics items. i know only about very few online CCG's that allow trading. i think MTG Online has some sort of trade, Urban Rivals and Scrolls. This is not a nice feature, its a godda.mn must have.

Might and Magic isn't the best universe to make a CCG from anyway, and i think its very suspicious that every major publisher suddenly has needs for a CCG. All of course with minimal player win / maximal publisher win principle. No trade, simple mechanics, too easy to learn, themed with thier own franchise makeing them a different form of advertising. Imagine yourself watching tv and insead of a break you have to play a how i met your mother" CCG for the show to continue. (:D could become the next big thing in future entertainment. The Touch-TV hahahaha)

reviewText: I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game. It's got a great reward system for early players to increase there card count and give them a chance to build new decks, as well as daily rewards for veteran players to earn new cards through game play. As long as you go into it knowing that people who have played for a long time or play a lot are going to have a more robust card collection than you (which will yield a certain advantage) you will not be disappointed. Honestly I've found that being a smarter player will usually trump a deck with better cards.\n\nMy advice if you start playing: check the forums for how you can earn cards. There are lots of little tricks to getting more cards/the cards you want.

reviewText: I am new to the game, but I do have and play magic IRL, considering that this free game still forces you to spend money on cards to completely own your opponents makes me want to laugh. I've spent enough on magic cards to know not to play an online version after spending hundreds on cards. But I thought hey, it can't be that bad, for new players even. NO, ranked matches, be prepared to get squashed. All the matches I have played have been with inferno players, so I'm going to assume that inferno is the ultimate race in this free game. I also don't see how they think me being lv 1 with very little choice of cards have any chance against a completed fire deck. And I don't see why the campaign requires you to face these OP players online. I know how to play the game, and I am good at it, but this does not feel like the real game. So yeah P2W, I don't care if I will be missed or not, cause this game does not have the feeling it does IRL, I will probably try Hearthstone. To anyone who are trying to decide whether or not to try this game. No.

reviewText:
I'm torn about this game.
On one hand it requires a good amount of strategy, planning, focus and cunning. It makes you think hard about your actions to the point where you're pondering the turn you're in the and turn to come. Choosing between moving and attacking can decide victory or defeat, hinging on knowledge and foresight. The factions are well-varied enough to make each one feel like a different kind of experience every time you switch. Plus getting achievements usually yield some type of reward like a card, sometimes a pack, in-game currency or just unlocking a new feature.

However...in usual form, Ubisoft is trying it damndest to make sure they mess up the experience by overcharging on everything and messing with your money. The packs are far too overpriced for what they offer and it feels especially galling when you buy a pack and end up with mostly common cards UNLESS you buy the special packs with the paid currency, then you're guaranteed premium" cards whereas the packs bought with in-game currency you only have a 1-in-6 chance.
Speaking of the paid currency
date: they try and make it so you always have some of it left over
recommended: just under the amount you need to buy another pack
hoursPlayed: so you always have that messing with your head. If you do the math you cannot help but feel like they purposely priced the packs so you always just don't have enough to finish off your seals or are left with just enough to where you can't hope to do anything with the remainder. Doesn't help that with this last update there's even less things in the store to buy with the in-game currency
voteText: the old starter packs seemed to have gotten shoved off into the void.\nAnd just for the sake of my own gripe the practice A.I. couldn't be more obvious with the fact that it cheats if it was playing with it's deck face-up and spread out over the table. I have too many examples of times where I'm getting a card's use negated before I even play it or my new-found advantage turns into a complete board wipe.\nAs it stands I cannot. in good faith. recommend this game. It can be quite addictive but Ubisoft's greed shines through and ruins the experience. Better priced packs or regular sales might get me to look upon this game with more favor but if I know Ubisoft like I think I do

reviewText:
WHAT HAPPENED??
This game was pretty cool, I had a few gripes but generally still fun... now with new update I'm nolonger getting seals whilst I level (only gold and xp) so I'll assume these have been vastly cut down and made pretty rare now?, and where have most of the packs gone? now ALL i can get with gold (coz im not earning seals anymore for some reason) is either 1 pack of 12 (which also comes with ZERO chance of a wildcard) or starter packs?! Everything else now requires seals?!  :(

Aside from the obvious, this sucks becuase now there are many many players that had a MUCH EASIER time building tough decks (pre latest update) than any newcomer to the game (unless they want to plough some cash into it) so they have a much tough challenge ahead of them in pvp - an instant disadvantage.

Now, I'm not against paying for games, I often do put a little hard earned cash into the games I play to spice them up or sometimes I'm just swayed to purchase purely because I love the work and want to support the developers...

Now one of my previous gripes was how you started to feel the pinch of playing for free as you got higher and higher in rank, It was obvious that the dynamicly changing ranking system at the time was designed intentionally this way by making it possible for level 5's to play level 20's+ purely because they hit a few a winning streaks and their rank went up... hence, players would quite quickly start to feel they needed better and better cards faster and faster!  BUT this was still passable, and I continued to play regardless of this irritation..  BUT now I feel like this pinch and need to spend money is placed on the players right from the get-go.

Well, as much as I was enjoying this game previsouly, I'm removing this game out of principle.

To be honest, I'm pretty sad to see it die, and also pretty disgusted.

reviewText:
I'm 120 hours in to the game now, spread out over a few months.

This game has a lot of ups, and a lot of downs.


The Good -

More than a fair amount of cards.
Strategy is very important, so even rich kids can't always dominate.
Easy to learn and get skilled at.
Built in streaming capabilities.
Queue times to get in to a match are generally between 1 and 10 seconds.


The Bad -

Lack of a social environment. You can only meet players by running in to them in a random matchup.
Cards cannot be traded.
If you want good cards, you have to either put in hours and hours of dedication, or empty your wallet.


Overall -

I would recommend giving this game a try, if you like turn-based card games. It is easy to learn, and fun to play. It's also great if you get a friend in to it, and you two can build up your decks to face off against eachother. However, I would NOT recommend spending cash on the game. The amount of cards you get for the amount of cash you spend is very unreasonable, and you'll end up spending a ton of money, for a chance at a good card.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being a long time Heroes of Might and Magic fan, I saw this free to play game on STEAM and gave it a try. So here are my main thoughts after 10 hours play.

For the HOMM fans, the lore and artwork and creature / building / spell names are taken right out of the 6 strategy games, so you will feel right at home with that. I had played some Magic The Gathering, but always became bewildered at the sheer amount of cards available - not to mention problems with compatibilty of decks. With Duel of Champions you don't have to worry about that. Sure there are far less cards (around 670 split between the 6 factions) but you certainly have enough to make multiple decks of each faction or even a dual deck. The gameplay is fast and easy to learn but hard to master. I won about 20 of my first 30 games and this allowed me to buy, with in game money, a handful of reinforcement packs and also 3-4 powerful cards to beef up my deck. My winning streak continues and it's great fun. As I am going up in ELO the players are becoming more challenging but that is all part of the fun.

A word about money, because I read some negative things on Steam Reviews concerning this. You are given a free deck of your chosen faction at the start with everything you need to play. After playing the tutorial and the first single player campaign (an extended tutorial really) you are given A LOT of free money. After leveling up (which happens fast at the beginning) you are given MORE free money, plus wildcards. Earning some easy to get achievements in PVP games will net you even MORE MONEY and free reinforcement packs and even wildcards. So in short, if you add all that up - you could afford to make a very strong deck within about 2-3 days without spending a dollar of real money. I'm sure that as you advance through the ranks in PVP you will hit a point where you might be tempted to buy some extra cards, and this game is very good and why should you not support the developers a little? I liked it so much I bought cards to the cost of about an average in-store game and ended up with FOUR DECKS and about 20 epic creatures. Needless to say I'm competitive now.

Some things do need improving. The general UI and it would be nice if the game made use of an HD resolution to it's full potential - something here seems that the PC version wasn't thought out enough after they made the I-PAD version. I hear they are addressing this very shortly. But apart from the odd cosmetic problems, that's really all I can think of.

So come be a powerful hero, raise an army and see if you can advance through the ranks with us. It takes less than 30 seconds to find a game at any time of the day.

reviewText:
This game is a really good game for you to play if you ever become bored. If you have ever played Magic: The Gathering, I can guarantee you that you will love this.

The rules are, you pick a faction, get a hero, and have to keep your hero alive every match while killing other heroes with other monsters. Sounds simple, right? The thing that makes this card game more complex and addictive is that there are loads of cards, combos and strategies to choose from. Plus, with the new Griffin Bane update, it is better than ever, with at least a few more heroes for each faction.

There are 6 factions in the game, each with its own style of gameplay: Haven, Inferno, Necropolis, Sanctuary, Stronghold and Academy. Each has different cards which can turn the tide in your favour. For example, Necropolis decks can focus on killing others and bringing your dead back to life; Inferno decks can attack right from the first turn; you get the idea.

Overall, it is a great game. A full 10/10.

reviewText: This is legitimately a fun online card game.  It plays fairly quickly but there is enough variety in cards that deck building is pretty fun.  The game has a free-to-play model, but the only thing you get from spending money is the ability to collect rare cards more quickly.\n\nThe game has the basic card advantage
recommended: and tempo mechanics you would expect from any Magic-like card game.  The hooks for this game are:\nthat the board has a grid so that you have to position your monsters to block each other.\nthere is a front line and back line to the grid
hoursPlayed: so creatures can protect each other.\nspells and effects hit locations on the grid
voteText: so positioning has a whole meta game to its self.\nyou play with a hero/commander card that changes how your deck plays and gives you special abilities.\nyou have three attributes (might=creatures
helpfulPercent: magic=spells
votesHelpful: fortune=tactics) and you raise one each turn.  Every card requires a certain level of at least one attribute.  So if you want to play a 6 might creature on turn six
votesTotal: you will have to put off playing a 6 magic spell or 6 fortune tactic until late in the game.\nThe nice thing about this game is that you get 99% of your cards through random packs and about 1% through a special store that lets you pick any single card you want for a very rare currency you can't buy directly.  There is no marketplace or website where everyone just buys the most powerful cards
votesFunny: so everyone has access to different cards (especially different rare cards) and almost no one has all the cards.  This means everyone has a slightly different deck.  It reminds of Magic before it got to the point where everyone just looks up the strongest deck lists online and buy the exact cards they need off Amazon or something.\n\nIf I were to compare it to Magic
commentsCount: I would say that there are fewer ways to win but the creature combat has more depth which mostly compensates for that.  There are seven or so factions but you can't combine them with other factions.  There are about seven schools of magic spell cards and you hero card will determine which one(s) you can use in your deck.\n\nThe way the game is set up
column16: you get a lot of cards early on--you get free starter decks for each faction just by beating someone else playing that faction
column17: and then you get a lot of the game's free currency to buy packs with from completing campaigns.  You can get access to most of the common and uncommon cards that you will want fairly easily without spending money.  The game tries to make money off you by selling you better packs with more rare
column19: and heroic cards for money.  However
column20: you will get new cards for free pretty steadily until you play through all the campaign games with all seven factions
column21: so that will give you plenty of time to decide if the game is worth spending real money.  They also sell limited-edition alternate art packs for holidays and such."

reviewText: Absolutely my favorite card game I've ever played. It's not perfectly easy to learn (the mechanics are quite easy, but in the beginning you'll be completely overwhelmed by the amount of cards you don't know), but definitely hard to master. Once you get the basics covered, you'll be hungry for building new decks and trying them out. And it's 100% F2P. When it comes to F2P, it's always TIME vs MONEY - but Duel of Champions breaks the rule and there's no need to spend a single penny.

reviewText:
As free-to-play card games go, this is a solid offering. That said, in the early stages I did feel pushed toward buying premium content, as the Hero cards required to 'unlock' additional factions are rare in individual booster packs.

The game does compinsate for this by offering a decent reward for first time completion of each campaign level (three/four victories per booster.) However, without the added customisability, it is possible to get stuck on some challenges.

Gameplay is well thought out, and visually the game is stunning. The game is easy to pick up, and open deck construction ensures that there is plenty of room for customising in game.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Yes, it's a collecteble card game (CCG) and that makes it Pay2Win by default. I won't argue about that at all. But at least this game gives you numerous ways to earn card packs from inside the game itself!

The whole Pay2Win obstacle tackled, now the game itself...

Graphics are nothing fancy when you think of it. The artwork for the cards however is very well done.
The music during the game is very pleasing as well and so far I haven't had the urge to turn off the sound.

The game mechanics are something to get used to. It's not your regular Magic: The Gathering" CCG. Duel of Champions offers a lot more and a lot less. Unlike M:tG you have a limited number of spots (8 total in 2 rows) to place your creatures
date: and some creatures can be placed only on of the rows. Then you have your spells and enchantments (just named differently here)
recommended:
which you do need to read twice before placing them. The description is kinda fuzzy from time to time (or rather from card to card) and I've made already a couple of mistakes because of it.
It's the buildings and events that make Duels of Champions interesting. Events (you need 8) are forced upon you to use and they can change the flow of a game. Buildings on the other hand are completely optional and when you put the right ones into your deck you can build a real powerhouse!

And yes
hoursPlayed: I did buy a couple of boosterpacks (around 25) with real money. Buy hey

reviewText:
This game has enthralled me.
It is likely the *best* online ccg currently available from a design and deckbuilding perspective.
This comes as a long time CCG gamer, MTG player, I' have many hours logged on every online CCG from Eredon to Urban Rivals to Altiel to Infinity and Might & Magic truly takes the cake as the best DECK BUILDING CCG available.The Standard and Weekly formats play out a very strategically. The Open Format is reminiscent of MTG's Legacy & Vintage where every little decision has huge ramifications. In terms of the major competitors we are set apart from MTG due to no ManaScrew and set apart from Hearthstone because there are more deckbuilding options.

My primary critiques are (1) lack of Draft format tournament and (2) I rather dislike Haven (playing as them and playing against them).

reviewText:
Over all I really like this game.
Pros:
Allows for a wide variety of tactical choices turn by turn.
Follows the Heroes of Might and Magic games pretty well in terms of unit abilities.
If you do the single player campaign it will give you over 1,200,000 gold worth in cards and prizes. To put this into perspective a booster costs 15,000
Daily log in rewards
Overall just plain fun.

Cons:
After completing the campaign obtaining new cards can be tedious as if you log in to complete the dailies only you will get a booster about every 2 days (not including the daily log in rewards).
Certain match ups can be really frustrating, Necropolis vs Necropolis for example.

In the end it is a fun card game and because it is free you loose nothing by trying it out.

reviewText:
It's true the game is dying, quite a few bugs and about a third of my duels timing out before anyone wins. The meta game has indeed also become stagnated due to a few overpowered strategies used by the majority of players.

That said though, it's still the best physical/online card games I've ever played, and I'm constantly working to build original and unexpected decks which can overcome the typical strategies. And even after all this time, there are still moments when I duel someone who brings some original strategy which I've never seen or heard of before, which completely catches me off guard. I'll speak to them and they'll tell me some story about how they were awake at night and had this idea, or it came to them in a dream or something, and well, I do the exact same ^^

Anyway, I don't know if I can really recommend new casual players to start this game. Truth is it's probably going to be annoying as hell to start playing now, but I would give it a try.

reviewText: An interesting take on the Heroes of Might and Magic universe, Duel of Champions falls short of capturing the allure of Magic: The Gathering. DoC contains both fresh and well known card game mechanics. Anyone who has played a traditional card game will feel comfortable with elements like deck building, color/theme binding (white = angels and healing, red = spells and demons, green = creatures and elves, etc), and player life count.\n\nHowever, the actual game play mechanics differ quite a bit. Instead of utilizing resource cards that you play, your total resource pool (mana) increases automatically each turn. This prevents the annoying mana screw" that permiates traditional card games. Each card requires one or more of your heroes static abilities to be a certain level (more on heroes further down). The different abilities are Might
date: Magic and Destiny. So a creature may cost 3 resources to put onto the battlefield
recommended: but you must have at least 2 might in order to play it. These stats are not "used" or expended
hoursPlayed: but a simple static threshold that you must meet in order to play more powerful cards.\n\nThe board is not dynamic like traditional card games. You have one hero
voteText: a deck
helpfulPercent: and a discard pile as normal. However
votesHelpful: you can only have 8 creatures at any given time - 4 in your back row (archers) and 4 in your front row (melee). Flying units can occupy either row
votesTotal: making them more flexible. While this prevents armies swelling with thousands of tokens
votesFunny: it also means you have to be very careful about which units you deploy - too many cheap units and you won't have any more room for your powerful creatures.\n\nHeroes - Duel of Champions revolves around the idea of the hero card. You can only have one hero
commentsCount: selected when you build your deck
column16: and they are always in play. The hero contains your life total and is the focus of attacks during the game. If your hero has 0 or less life
column17: you lose the game. Each turn
column18: the hero can use one of their special abilities. By default
column19: every hero can increase one of their stats (might
column21: or destiny) by 1. The majority of heroes can also pay 1 resource to draw a card. However
column22: the rare heroes have further special abilities at their disposal.\n\nHeroes compare best to Planeswalkers from MtG
column23: except you always have the hero you select and losing them means losing the game.\n\nUnlike the Heroes of Might and Magic series
column24: there are not artifacts to collect or equip. Each hero starts out at level 0 at the beginning of every game
column25: and experience only serves to effect your Elo rating.\n\nFree-to-Play: on the Pay-to-Win scale
column26: I'd rate this at about 9/10. Not surprising
column27: considering it's supposed to be a collectible card game. However
column28: this element is made far worse by three things:\n\n1) It's a collectible card game
column29: not a trading card game. That means you are unable to trade any of your cards - not for gold/seals or to other players.\n\n2) Premium packs give you special tokens that can be traded for specific cards. While free packs have a very
column30: very small chance of giving you these tokens
column31: it would take you months of playing to get enough tokens to trade in. Thus
column32: people who pay in can take elite cards that free players have little to no access to.\n\n3) Each new expansion set is much more powerful than the last
column33: so whoever drops $50+ is going to have a very distinct advantage over players with older cards.\n\nAt a glance
column34: the game seems cheaper than card games
column35: with a $5 purchase netting ~3 booster packs. However
column36: the inability to trade anything you find makes 90% of the cards worthless. Similar to MtG
column37: you can only have 4 of any type of card in your deck
column38: so you'll quickly end up with piles of useless commons that you can't get rid of or use.\n\nMultiplayer Only - Despite the initial apearance of single player missions
column39: there are a total of about 20 missions (including 5 training missions)
column40: that don't really tie into any kind of tangible story. They really amount to an extended tutorial and are only worthwhile for the gold and seals it gives you. If saved and used during a sale
column41: you get enough for one premium and one regular card box (around 250 cards) and enough tokens to trade for a single hero card.\n\nGraphics - I'm usually kind to smaller or indie games in this regard. However
column42: DoC was created first and formost for the ipad. They did nothing more than port it over to PC
column44: and a barely usable deck builder. Full screen mode simply adds a larger border and keeps all the content the same size. This must be the single most frustrating part of the game.\n\nSummary - While the game is fun (though desperately needs balance)
column45: the inability to trade cards with other players and the necessity to pay money for the newer card sets to have an even playing field subtracts substantially from the game's allure. Simply adding a trade mechanic (similar to how steam trading cards work) would go a very long way to fixing the game and keep non-paying and low-paying players interested. Also
column47: you're just throwing your money into a static board game
column48: not investing into a community driven collectible game.\n\nAt it stands
column49: only people with a decent amount of disposable income and extra time to kill will enjoy this game. Everyone else will probably find too little for the cost of admission.\n\nFinal Score - 5/10"

reviewText:
UPDATE: This game had been officially abandoned by Ubisoft and will no longer receive any content updates. The matchmaking servers are still running and there are still a few dedicated players to play with online - but the meta had gone stagnant due to no new updates.
______________________

Fun and highly-polished collectable card game with interesting mechanics, fast gameplay, tons of card variety, and nice card illustrations.

Tip for new players who wanna try this out: Register with a referral code to get 6 starter packs for free, it will give you over 200 cards to start with and all 6 starting heroes for free - an immense help at starting your collection. My referral code is 4VNCCD or use this link below:
https://signup.duelofchampions.com/portal/in
dex/DOC_world_02_0010_06_200_12_0614_00?
refId=4VNCCD Pros and cons:
Pros:
+Fun single player campaign missions that gives nice rewards like booster packs and gold to buy more packs
+Tons of cards to collect that can be easily unlocked by playing through the campaign
+Weekly 8 player rules-of-the-week tournaments and monthly jackpot tournaments
+Creatures, abilities, spells and heroes are set to the Might and Magic mythos
+Good music and awesome card illustrations
+Six factions to play that each have their own unique mechanics and lots of hero cards to choose from add a lot of variety and depth to the game
+It's not Hearthstone
Cons:
-Small community
-The competitive meta focuses on only a few cookie-cutter builds
-No draft mode" yet that's similar to Hearthstone's Arena (though Ubisoft has said they are working on it)
-Need a Uplay account (you don't need to install Uplay - just a Uplay account; either register or use an account you already have)
-It's not Hearthstone
I really recommend this game to players wanting to get into a collectable card game without spending money to have fun; I also highly recommend this to card game players who want to try something more complex than Hearthstone."

reviewText: Loved the Might & Magic RPGs, loved the Heroes of Might & Magic Strategic Series, loved Magic the cardgame. Hate this game. Sure it's free and no you don't have to buy anything. But the amount of grinding, just to scrounge enough coins to be able to 'buy' a booster pack. Or having a solo campaign that is primarily a couple of paragraphs of text (what lore?), but to actually continue, you first have to beat 5 PvP online games. You want to fully complete the campaign? Wait, don't finish it with one deck, no you need to beat each round all over again with ALL the other factions. So that will mean getting the starter deck, replaying campaigns or PvP, just to scrounge enough gold to buy booster packs again and repeat all over again.\nIt gets too boring too fast.\nAlso you do want to consider actually buying things with real money, because some cards are way better than others, wile having similar summoning costs. So you either grind or you buy. That is, if you want to have a minimal chance of beating the mandatory PvP, as other players just happen to have extremely powerfull finetuned decks, even at you start-level.

reviewText:
Within the first hour of playing I was blown away. DoC is (in my opinion at least) the best digital CCG experience available today. Yes, that means that it's better than Hearthstone and all of the Magic the Gathering games released to date, as the former is far more simpistic (dare I say casual?), and the latter is little more than a hobbled version of the physical experience.

With distinct and varied factions, each offering unique playstyles, coupled with great art and Might & Magic fanservice, I would recommend that everyone who has even a passing interest in CCGs download DoC and give it a go.

To get you started, you can use the following referral code (yes, I went there. I'm not proud):

reviewText:
Originally posted by damienmq:
PROS:
- Single player Campaign that takes more than a week to complete as it is hard.
- Lots of GOLD & CARDS earned from single Campaign.
- Deep strategy with LOTS of SPELLS
- Quick matches from 5 minutes to long ones of 20 minutes (that I love)
- AMAZING DARK FANTASY
- Levelling up gives you experience and gold to buy more packs
- It's FREE ( just try and see for your self)

CONS:
- It takes sometimes 2 minutes to get an adversary.
- It takes a few days to understand the mechanics of the game. (as it is complex, and GREAT!)
- Sometimes the randomization of the cards you get in your starting hand is flawed (getting 3 copies of one card 2 of another and 2 of another is strange when it happens a once or twice a day)
Yeah, verry good F2P Strategy Game with Cards!   10/10

reviewText:
To me it's the best card game. Mechanics are diverse, cards are truly beautiful. The client is just ok, sometimes it lags, sometimes it crash (even when you open a card pack that maybe you have even payed for and that's really grievous); the same (client) feature just decent graphics and sounds, but the battleground is just mediocre. You can play it for free since the game sort people by calculating their relative skill level, so generally you will not find an opponent much stronger (or weaker) than you. You can climb the ranking by buying some card packs or box set (better the latter) having the chance to acquire better cards but you can acquire them even spending the actual currency (Gold) inside the game. You can acquire Gold by fighting against your opponents or completing quests and when you have enough you can buy some card packs.

There is a single player campaign but it's limited so you will want early to play it in a multiplayer fashion and face human opponents. The community is strong but Factions are a bit unbalanced, Inferno is the strongest at the top of the ranking (and the easiest to play) and Necropolis is the strongest at the bottom, but other Factions are (just) playable too, simply not so competitive.
There are various ways to play the game (even without too much committment) and there are tournaments held continuosly.

reviewText: I was really happy and impressed with the game. I wish the community was larger honestly, it's a very intricate game. I haven't found a match that was just super stellar simple; I was constantly being forced to think hard about every move. Even with intro decks you can have a very involving duel, and this game starts you off with several decks and gives a lot of stuff for free before you need to start using your own money.\nOne of my favorite card games ever. If it was to make it big and muster a mighty community, I'd love to dive head first into it. I wish it had Hearthstone's arena gamemode however, it'd be sick, but I can understand that a not-so-popular game can't afford to give away such resources.

reviewText:
A strategically fun and addictive CCG that is often overlooked in favour to its contemporaries

Pros:- Fun and addictive once you learn its rules
- Requires some strategic placement with units\cards as it's fairly complex
- Contain 6 factions offering great card variety in the event you tire of one faction
- You can get a fairly powerful deck once you complete the campaign without buying power
- Having OP cards don't necessarily mean victory
- Visually and audibly appealing
- You need a UPlay account but you don't need UPlay service to play the game, given that it's an Ubisoft game that's a major plus

Cons:- Appears to exhibit some P2W aspects but then again it's F2P so what's new here
- May be a bit unbalanced for certain factions (I'm looking at you Necro Hero with 2 cost cripple power BS)
- Updates may unbalance certain cards and factions but is mostly resolved via patches

Limitations:- Learning curve may be a bit steep to newcomers as it plays more differently than other CCGs (Not really an issue for me though)
- Sometimes crashes for no reason but runs smoothly with no problems the majority of time
- Contains a special breed of A-hole player who likes to make you suffer even though you're on 1HP (Player base issue not game issue)

Verdict:An excellent free strategic CCG that requires some time to learn and master its intricacies however be warned it does exhibit certain P2W aspects but it's not P2W as having OP cards does not guarantee victory. Overall it may be one of Ubisoft's best games currently

reviewText:
Overall a nice, good looking game.
I like the layout of  the playing field and it's a well thought out game.
The art is very nice and the game works smooth....BUT

It's, like 99 % of the games nowadays, an obvious pay to win game.
Online you come across players who spent actual money to get good cards
and in campaign you are bound to run into OP opponents if you are not willing
to spend money on better and rare cards.
So keep in mind, if you are not willing to spend your cash on this you wont get that far!

With that in mind, I reccomend the game to people who either don't care about being really good and just want a fun deck builder or people who are willing to spent cash.

reviewText:
Might and Magic: Duel of Champions looks really sweet at first glance, but after spending some time with the game it really starts to show that It's a wasted potential (sadly).

The game starts of with a small demonstration of the mechanics of the game, and these also feels very fresh and new for card games in general. But after several matches you just realize that It's really not that exciting, especially when you have one deck and no cards to tweak it with. Even after getting some of the other decks it just feels bland and boring, and even though there are a lot of strategy involved, the game just feels more or less like a snore-fest.

But it doesn't stop here, in order to get a decent deck or even get the cards you want, you would have to play this game forever. This is a pay to win game straight through, and spending all that time with a concept that gets extremely boring pretty fast is a no-no. I don't mind pay features in games like these, but the difference it makes in buying vs not buying is extreme here, and that's why I can't recommend this game.

The concept is not for me, but I'm sure that there are a lot of people out there that finds it fun though. But if you want a great card game I will direct you to Magic the gathering instead.

Pros:

+New and fresh concept.
+Lots of varied cards (Interesting mix up in deck building)


Cons:

- Lack of variation of decks at the start of the game. (1 deck only)
- Payment barrier is HUGE
- No rewards when dueling your friends.
- A concept that gets very boring, very quick
- Non-existant combat animation.
- No instants.

Just uninstall after use ;)

reviewText:
Just wait for Hearthstone to go into open beta.

There are a variety of reasons to stay away from this game, but most notably is balance, or rather, lack there of. the game loves to make complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t cards that make no sense. for instance, Haven has regen cards, awesome, however there are equal cost cards with lifedrain and no retaliation which entirely trumps any all all reason to ever want regen, as you will be able to attack and regen unless some special magic is in play.

Game also tends to be a very silly game of cat and mouse early due to the lanes (which also is a god awful system due to how they implimented it, and made some cards abuse it far too much)

its an interesting attempt, but its very stale in execution, tons of cards are completely garbage and not worth even touching while other (unique cards) are completely broken for no other reason than you only get one of them" which would be cool but this is a game about drawing cards
date: these things being incredibly broken means that if you get yours and your opponent does not
recommended: you have a great chance of kicking their ♥♥♥.\n\nThe balance in games like hearthstone or scrolls isn't perfect
hoursPlayed: but its a hell of alot better than this
voteText: not to mention their deck building style is much better (in duel of champions you can have 50 cards or more in a deck
helpfulPercent: in hearthstone you are limited to 30
votesHelpful: which really restricts how you choose your cards
votesTotal: rather than have to pile cards in your deck just to counter discard decks)\n\n6/10"

reviewText: Reason why i love this game so much is because i play magic the gathering with the physical cards not just online. Might and magic helped me understand the actual card game while teaching methods of a whole different one. Now yes there are games on steam, like the actual magic the gathering game. So why choose this one? because it's a change in venue. Playing one game over and over again will get boring so this mixes up the change in gameplay. What i liked the most was how it taught me the difference between the lives your action cards have and your life. The champions i put out will die but it doesnt affect me, when it affects me thats how i know i may lose, or are needing to put down more cards to keep me from taking damage.

reviewText:
The game came up in my showcase line after the new Steam update and as a fan of the classic Might and Magic franchise i gave it a try. I played the tutorial and found a gorgeous card game that seems to trash other digital TCG. After the tutorial it even gives you a try out for every faction in the game, each one of the classical Might and Magic factions (Inferno, Sanctuary etc.), whereby you are pumped to start your first own game with whichever starter deck you choose, just to get smashed into the wall that is UPlay (not).

I evaded UPlay since Ubisoft started the thing and for good reason and unfortunately Ubisoft still think their flawed 'service' helps them with whatever they  think it does (in my opinion it does nothing positive and a ton negative things).

After that disappointment i went back to the store page and there was nowhere a hint that UPlay is necessary for this game (only that it 'Requires agreement to a 3rd-party EULA', which doesn't really count). So i thought i write this review for other poor souls that look out for this game and maybe can be saved before they get lured into this trap.

UPlay (NOT)!

reviewText:
I do recommend this game, but it must be understood that players that started during the Heart of Nightmare expansion are limited to doing Standard Ranked Games. That is the only mode which I feel new players will have a chance to win, as only Base Set II and HoN cards are allowed in the Deck. These packs are available to anyone for gold, so no need to purchase seals [unless you wish to be a pay2win player which is also fine].

I believe that if you are a player who started when this game first came out and have an incredible cardpool of the first 5 sets, and had a decently built deck, then you may be able to do fine in the Open Ranked games. I am that type of player, I have a good cardpool since the Base Set I through Forgotten Wars [Not much came from 5Towers anyways]. I did buy a couple boxes. Right now I am at 1500 Elo.

So really you must become a Pay2Win player if you started during the HoN expansion, and you wish to play in Open Ranked Games. Your other option is to make the best out of the Base Set II and HoN cards which is doable but you will still have certain cards that are not available to you but available to people who started before HoN.

I must put emphasis it is very important to join the Ubisoft / Duel of Champions forum
http://forums.ubi.com/forumdisplay.php/333-Might-amp-Magic-Duel-of-Champions?s=3c98aca04e192221b4c939aa85803e46

It is VERY important that you go to the Deck Building / Strategy section of that forum.
Post on there and ask for help!

Very important to watch WorldofEnclase on youtube and his Deck Building Guide (There are 5 Episodes)
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCARezaDUyq3r3gwmIr6W2Dw

Also the following website is a Deck Builder's Paradise, in which you can craft a deck and have a place to save it.
You will especially need this website because players on the forum will ask you for a link to your deck idea, and they are more than awesome to give you a hand.
http://mmdocking.com/

I know that a lot of players are mad with the changes, making packs from the older expansions cost seals instead of gold.
Taking out the Seal rewards from leveling up and instead replacing it with Wild Card and/or Gold rewards.

Although the Daily Quests are kinda nice, but I have to say that most likely only be able complete quests that related to the single faction you have chosen.

GG

reviewText:
Hi friends,

this is a very interesting game! Defenitely try it! This is NOT just a boring card game.
The beginning is a bit hard and sometime frustrating, but when get in higher levels and buy some cards with the gold that you got from duels, this game makes many hours of fun.
It has a nice tutorial, but the campaign could be a bit longer. It prepares you for the different races you will meet in the duels - of course the players will be harder as the computer.
The ranking system (you will meet players with your duel level) is balanced in the most times. When a player bought some new and better cards with the different resources he will get in the possible ways, he will be harder to defeat of course.
Just dont give up, think about your tactics, use your cards wisely and optimize your deck - your time will come.
A nice game to chill out.
Different modes make a nice content. Manage to finish the campaign, practice against AI, friends or other players, play real and ranked duels or even tournaments. Nice options to get and sacrifice cards and build new decks!
Buying gold and seal for real money is a bit expensive in my opinion, but you have to devide on your own. For just playing the game it is not really needed.

Thumbs up for the friendly community - no flames as long as i played the game! Add me if you want.


See you in game
mr. tobsson

reviewText:
I really really want to recommend this game to many people, it's fun with diversity, many heroes and factions. Fans of Might & Magic series will be very delighted. But ultimately there are certain problems that keeps casual player away.
...
1, there is so little things you can do with gold. You can only purchase 2 card packs, they don't have any wildcards, and keep on giving me repetititive cards. It's annoying, waste of gold, and hard to build a decent deck without commitment in either time or real money.
2, no real trading, turn out this game is more to collective card game.
3, you don't win card from matches, not even duplicates.
4, reward from playing PvP matches is so little and they are based on total time of play, not per win. Eg: 5 minutes game yield just around 500 gold. While the cheapest card pack costs 15000 gold. of course the latest campaign reward changes to 5000 gold per mission is nice, but they are after all, finite and can't be repeated.
5, not on Android platform

voteText: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At first this game seem great! It had a wonderful tutortial that teached you how to play the game. Your first few matches between NPCs aren't too hard and aren't too easy, progression seems good! You get like 5 free packs to open as well.

However, the ball is dropped after you reach around lvl 4 which I did. Everything becomes a korean grind. You get enough in-game gold buy yourself a handful of packs and you start with a few packs too Around 3-5 or so I believe after that your screwed. The campaign is extremely short and you could be through that in a 2-3hrs. So no more bonus gold from missions.

Now you do get some seals from playing through the game at the moment of this post I had over 1,000 which would get me a card box of that value which would give me 10 more packs. So that is nice. However seals are the cash shop currency, so I'm not entirely sure if I'd want to spend that just yet.

With PvP matches you get around 800-1000 gold. The cheapest pack you can get is 12,500 gold. Roughly 13 matches minium to just buy ONE card pack of 12. I don't recall the amount of gold you get if you lose. So there's that to consider too. There are these 2 card packs that you can get but they are 2,000 a piece. So 2-4 matches to just get a 2 card pack?

Finally, the card packs themselves is just evil. In this game the cards you can use both monsters/magic/fortune cards are all determined by the hero card you have. So you could spend 12.5k on a card pack and not get a single card you can use because the cards in that pack does not match your hero's faction or their school of magic. So finding the cards you need to improve your deck will be a shot in the dark every time you open a card pack.

I could've easily fallen in love with this game. I had played a Yugioh card game on the DS for endless of hours yet I'll be forced to grind and play with the same deck for dozens of times before I begin getting cards that can help improve/evolve my game. Sadly it's not worth the trouble. I rather go look at one of the other new card games that have came out or will be in the future. (Scrolls, Hearthstone, SolForge, Shadow Era, etc.)

Oh well, back to Yugioh.

reviewText:
The game is very good, it's a 3D platform card game, very similar to Magic: The Gathering or Infinity Wars. It works on iPad and probably all touchscreens and it has Twitch add-in! Despite other weird-never-seen-before options...
The only reason i'm not into it right now is because the mechanics involved are quite different from the games I mentioned earlier and for me the game is more difficult to interpret and can be confusing sometimes.

My opinion is: give it a try. If you like it, keep it, like me. But if you think the concept is too far off of what you're used to, you should not play it. Anways, I recommend it.

reviewText:
As a nerdy kid in middleschool, I spent plenty a lunchtime playing CCGs (I always called then TCGs?). I was no stranger to Magic: The Gathering, Pokemon the TCG, Yu-Gi-Oh and many other lesser known card games. It's been many years since I found a CCG that help my interest, let alone one that I actually felt warranted my giving it some money. The drought has ended. I have found a new CCG that has sucked me in.

The game is simple to jump into if you are familiar with CCGs. Your objective is to attack your opponents hero until they run out of health. The game elegantly handles problems some other CCGs have, such as resources. Resources, needed to pay for monsters you summon and spells you cast, increase by 1 every turn automatically. This eliminates problems other CCGs have, like in Magic, where your game can be ruined by never drawing enough Mana cards, or drawing nothing but. The game is also quick. If playing a competent opponent, most games end in under 15 minutes. Theres a tournament mode where each player only gets 7 minutes total and the vast majority of the time, this is more than enough to win by wiping out your opponent.

The cards effects are simple and can be understood with one reading. The art looks great and is based, of course, on the robust M&M universe. Factions include Haven (high defense and healing), Barbarian (units have haste and atk power that steadily increases), Necromancers (lots of instadeath spells and reviving units), Infernals (high damage swarm/rush deck), Forgotten War (aka Sorcerers. Lots of potent spells that can be reused and the ability to banish cards from play) and Sanctuary (oriental theme, momentum deck where units give adjacent units perks creating a snowball effect).

A lot of good ideas are borrowed from other CCGs and come together to form this well made, fun game. It's also free to play, which is a huge plus in my book. Newcomers get to choose 1 basic deck from Haven, Barbarian, Necro or Infernal. Decks consist of 6o cards minimum and this includes 8 month cards (month cards are drawn each turn outside of the playfield and have effects on both players ie: for the next 2 turns, all spells cost 1 less resource to play). When you win an online match, you gain some gold and exp. Everytime you level up, you gain a stash of gold which can be used to buy booster backs or other decks.

A LOT of people make it to the high ranks of play and never spend money, which is great. That being said, once you clear the campaign and hit higher levels, the speed at which you come into money greatly slows down. The game also has 3 kinds of currency. Gold (common) which buys booster packs and some decks, Seals (uncommon, awarded upon completing certain campaign levels and leveling up) which buys decks and better booster packs and Wildcards (rare, only gained by buying booster packs, must be used to buy specific cards you want). If you want to play competitively without spending money, it can be done, but will take a lot of time. I personally, liked the game so much, I have made a couple of purchases to give me a better card slection.

All and all, I'm very happy with the game and play it pretty much daily. Recommend.
