reviewText:
DoC after Heart of Nightmares

Summary
DoC is a very good and deep card game with a lot of strategic options. Especially the card art is very nice, and it's a lot of fun to collect cards. The new concept for rotating formats that was introduced with Base Set 2 is good, but suffers because of poor execution.
The new economic model that was introduced recently is a big disadvantage for new players, and if you are into competitive play you might want to keep in mind that you have to spend around 30€ if you don't want to get crushed by players with access to more cards.
Overall you should definitly give DoC a shot, especially if you are on the look for a CCG with a strong tactical complexity.

My experience with the game
I have been playing DoC for half a year now. My recorded hours on Steam are around 50, but only because I play on the iPad most of the time (Steam and iOs sync seamless). In total I have played around 1.500 matches now, witch is enough to give you a educated review of the game.

What is a Collectible Card Game
If you are totally new to this, a short summary. In DoC you buy packs, just like in the old Magic the gathering times, only that you can get packs for free. From this packs you get random cards for several factions witch you can combine to form decks that are 59 or more cards (but stick to 59). You use your deck to compete with other players online. A battle basically consists of playing cards and hitting your opponent until he is dead.

The changes with the latest patch
Recently, with the Heart of Nightmares update the game was seperated into 2 Formats: Open (all cards count) and Standard (a selected pool of cards counts). This move was necessary because the card base for DoC was growing fast and it became very hard for new players to get into the game. Base Set 2 was intended to make it easier for new players to get into the game (witch failed, more on that later).

Basically Base Set 2 is a collection of 300 cards, witch are a little less then 50% of all existing cards. Especially some extremly powerful rare & epic cards have been removed from Standard, because those were dominating the game and hard to get (i.e. hard for beginners). The idea was to create a reduced card pool that was easier to collect and reserve open format for the experienced players. Unfortunatly this didn't work out.

The (dreaded) economic changes
Those ruined the game for beginners. Period. Before I can explain why, you have to understand a few concepts for DoC regarding the economy.

There are two ways to get cards, you buy packs (with gold or seals) or you change Wildcards into specific cards you need (Wildcards are the dust in Hearthstone if you have experience with that game).
Seals are the premium currency and can only be obtained with real money (after BS2). The real premium currency though are Wildcards, because even with seals you can only buy packs and have to rely on RNGesus to give you the cards you need.

When introducing the changes for BS2 the developers said they would remove the options for obtaining free seals BUT they would up the amount of wildcards you can get. Unfortunatly that didn't happen, after the patch I'm getting EVEN LESS wildcards then before AND no more seals for free.

Let's break it down without to much detail: As a new player you will recieve massive amounts of gold (witch buys you a lot of packs), 1-5 wildcards a week and no seals. That basically means you will have to rely on RNGesus to build your deck and that's no problem in the lower ranks (all other new players are going to have the same problem), but boy you are going to get crushed when you get into competitive levels.

Also at this point there is no way of getting into open without opening your wallet or two years of constant power grinding (no kidding, it's actually about two years until you have the necessary wildcards for a single competitive open deck). This really needs a massive fix right now.

Some beginners Tips
First, the game shifted towards Necropolis & Inferno with the patch, if you want to know witch faction to choose. A ranking would be:
First: Necropolis, Inferno
Second: Academy, Stronghold
Third: Sanctuary
Way last: Heaven

At this point there isn't a single competitive deck for Heaven, they are really sub-par right now. Don't choose heaven if you don't want to get crushed constantly.

Also consider getting the starter packs for all factions for 10€. This will help you a lot, because it's close to impossible to get other heros / factions in the beginning. And, while quite hard, you can start finishing the campaign witch will give you lot's of gold, 300 cards for open and 40 wildcards (doesn't sound like much but is a real value). Last but not least, there are quite a bunch of daily quests like win 2 games with necropolis" and you need a working deck to finish those.

Best try to stay in the lower ranks at the beginning. It's tempting to get to champion as fast a possible to get daily quests with wildcards but a daily quest doesn't help you if you can't complete it because everyone else is just too strong (and they can't be canceled so you will be stuck with them).

Also keep away from Tournaments completly. Free tickets are really rare now
date: save them until you have a really good deck that can actually win.\n\nCheck out the offical forums
recommended: there is a lot of advice on deckbuilding etc. there (helped me a lot in the beginning). Just a quick note for beginners: Limit you deck to exactly 59 cards and don't include creatures with any requirement higher then 5. There are a lot of beefy creatures that look awesome but there is an insane amount of removal in this game and they will just get killed and you will loose.\n\nAnd last but not least: Don't spend your wildcards until you are absolutly sure what you are doing. Just don't
hoursPlayed: you will regret it later

reviewText:
This game is essentially Hearthstone, except it's been out for a while longer.

Rather than having playable reasources, like Magic: The Gathering, or restricting the number of cards you can play per turn like SolForge, you have a single resource meter, which increases by 1 each turn, and that's how much stuff you can play that turn. You also draw a card each turn as well.

Unlike Hearthstone, this game places value on positioning, as there are 8 spaces (2x4) on each side of the board, and you can only attack our opponent if the opposing 2 spaces are empty. Otherwise, you can attack the creature(s) there. There is also a distinction between ranged (can attack either of the two opposing spaces) and melee/flyer (can attack the closest opposing space) creatures. And when attack, creatures also retaliate.

Cards have a faction, and usually an element as well. The basis of each deck is a Hero, which determines what factions and elements you can use in your deck (as well as the factionless and elementless cards any deck can use).

In addition to their resource cost, cards have an additional limiting factor on their play. Each hero has a Might, a Magic and a Valor? stat. Each turn you can increase one of these stats for free (or pay 1 resource to draw a card), and your stat must be equal to or greater than the requirement on the card to play it. It is not a resource you spend, just a limiter on what can be played, probably to ensure proper scaling of the battle.

Players start at 20 life each, and there are a variety of heroes, some which have special abilities, which you can use instead of increasing a stat or buying a card. They also have different starting stats (the base heroes start with 1 Might, 1 Magic & 2 Valor).

The game is fairly enjoyable, and it has a very well done campaign mode, which really helps you learn the game. It also has a leveling mechanic where you gain experience from battles. Not sure what all you can do when you level up yet. It has daily rewards, and the more days you long in in a row (up to 7), the better the rewards you get (but if you miss a day, you could lose all those rewards).

Overall, I think I would recommend this game, however there are a few issues with it. The cards from the first base set (which will be most of the cards you get in the starter decks), don't have creature abilities explained on the card consistently. This can make it difficult to plan strategy. There doesn't seem to be an upper limit on resource generation, meaning if a game last long enough, you get to the point of casting your entire hand, and then some. Also, each card is required to have 4 event cards, which flip over (along with your opponents 4) each turn, and provide either a purchasable or ongoing affect. However, your opponent can use these events as well, and there's not a lot of variety to them. There's not a lot of ways to use them to strengthen your deck, and they hinder you as much as help you I'd say, 80% of the time.

I would still recommend Magic or SolForge over this game, but if you're looking for another CCG to play, this is definitely a fun game.

reviewText:
القرآن)، ولا تتم الصلاة (وعبادات أخرى) في الإسلام إلا بإتقان بعض العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير من أهم الأعمال الدينية والفكرية اليهودية في العصور الوسطى. وأثّر انتشار الإسلام، وتأسيسه دولاً، في ارتفاع مكانة اللغة العربية، وأصبحت لغة السياسة والعلم والأدب لقرون طويلة في الأراضي التي حكمها المسلمون، وأثرت العربية تأثيراً مباشراً أو غير مباشر على كثير من اللغات الأخرى في العالم الإسلامي، كالتركية والفارسية والأمازيغية والكردية والأردوية والماليزية والإندونيسية والألبانية وبعض اللغات الإفريقية الأخرى مثل الهاوسا والسواحيلية والتجرية والأمهرية و الصومالية، وبعض اللغات الأوروبية وخاصةً المتوسطية كالإسبانية والبرتغالية والمالطية والصقلية، كما أنها تُدرَّس بشكل رسمي أو غير رسمي في الدول الإسلامية والدول الإفريقية المحاذية للوطن العربي.
العربية لغة رسمية في كل دول الوطن العربي إضافة إلى كونها لغة رسمية في تشاد وإريتريا وإسرائيل. وهي إحدى اللغات الرسمية الست في منظمة الأمم المتحدة، ويُحتفل باليوم العالمي للغة العربية في يسمبركذكراعتماد العربية بين لغات العمل في الأمم المد
واللغة العربية من أغزر اللغات من حيث المادة اللغوية، فعلى سبيل المثال يحوي معجم لسان العرب لابن منظور من القرن الثالث عشر أكثر من ألف مادة، بينما في اللغة الإنجليزية فإن قاموس صموئيل جونسون وهو من أوائل من وضع قاموساً إنجليزياً من القرن الثامن عشر يحتوي على ألف كلم
تحتوي العربية على حرفاً مكتوباً. ويرى بعض اللغويين أنه يجب إضافة حرف الهمزة إلى حروف العربية، ليصبح عدد الحرو تُكتب العربية من اليمين إلى اليسار - ومثلها اللغة الفارسية والعبرية وعلى عكس الكثير من اللغات العالمية - ومن أعلى الصفحة إلى أسفلها.
العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير

reviewText:
(OKAY I DON'T RECOMMEND THIS GAME BUT I DON'T HATE IT)

kay so I was about to uninstall this game
but then I got to level 5
and I was able to access the Infernal Pit
and then I got rid of things and got better things with wildcards

seriously, it gets easier if you invest a few days in it. pvp is a little brutal if you don't have the cards (half the time, you will be cursing those Honor buffs and those Crippling debuffs) but still manageable.

technically I wouldn't actually recommend this game, it seems more pay-to-play than anything else (I am so tempted to pay) judging by the difficulty I am having amassing a deck, other than the one I started with, that is reasonably good, but it is still rather fun.

6/10 because I hate pay-to-play games, but I love the whole strategy-card-stuff.

reviewText:
TL DR:
pros:
+ open, standard, tournament modes are all really have different tastes and fun.
+ no hater, rager, as*holes so far
+ good ambient and combat soundtracks.
+ interesting cards.
+ achievements are pretty rewarding
+ deck building is so enjoyable
+ 2 pretty OP inferno cards get nerfed recently

cons:
- no balance between ...  pretty much anything.
- same strategies is being used over and over.(rush, rush, rush go snowball, turn 6 ggwp)
- why inferno so OP?
- lack of community sources. little guides avaliable, i want some brainstorming.
- some cards has no counter play.you just play it and opponent can do nothing but dying in pain.  (some examples; time lapse, bound succubus, prison)
- inferno is kinda annoying beacuse, it has all of excellent starting creatures, early spells to board clear(low cost, both single and multi target spells),and decent mid-late creatures to carry on.
- neutral cards generally too weak for their cost. i want to use them, but i cant :'(
- inferno is so fkn annoying. nerf it ffs.

So basically what i like in card games ; strategies with counter strategies, mind games, unique cards, creating my playstyle, reading some stuff about good players options and learn about current meta, constructing a deck and ofcourse collecting rare cards. With this said, lets return to the topic. MMDoC has no balance in factions, spells, events, minions, heroes actually nearly in anything. This game doesnt encourge wide variety of open and new strategies. Only very specific strats are usefull, you have to use a rush deck or 70% of the time you gonna lose very soon. There is no mind games(heartstone secrets, saving spells for combo etc). Some cards just dont pop out from boosters although you open dozens of packs but some cards pop out every fkin time.I just get 20 sea elves, 15 water elementals and 30 ♥♥♥♥♥♥ vultures, same cards always pop out. I am not looking for extra rare cards man, just gimme some different commons or maybe some other uncommons. I am just bored to see these same cards every time. I really like to read forums or some guides about the game i am playing, but there is so little things about the game's content to read which (i think) is caused by game itself because there is really little room for making new plays or decks-strategies in this game so people just write the same things over and over. So i am kinda dissapointed because game has much more potential imo. Lastly, dont invest money until you got a full idea of the game and unless you are certain that you gonna enjoy the game.

reviewText: I keep trying to accept this game as i love the Might and magic world but frankly this is insulting and im just done. balance doesnt exist and for as long as its been here the staff apparently could care less what we think and are never going to fix the game. you have generals who just show up and your deck loses period because they made generals hard counters to entire strategies. you have the new acedemy faction which makes no sense that it exists. by that point the game was already horribly unbalanced and then instead of addressing that they made it even worse. most people see an acedemy deck and just quit because why waste your time. seriously. this game is for the minds of children who dont have the ability to see their being played. although i think a 2yr old could see the balance issues with the game. i dont get what the developers are thinking. worst card game i have ever played. LONG LIVE MAGIC THE GATHERING! this attempt is pathetic. i couldve done better making a new card game out of sticky notes and crayon... really upsetting. take your epic world. and put the dam time in to make a fully supported game we can get behind. this franchise will be dead within the next 10 years if they dont start actually trying. really sad

reviewText:
Strategy Card Game Simulator
*Bug Free

Overall 2 out of 5
Complexity 3
Graphics 4
Immersive 3
Innovative 1
Game Pace 2

There’s nothing special about this card game, it’s much like many others available.
At the beginning, you get a basic set of cards, not enough to build a sound strategy for your Deck, but that’s fine for a starter.

The thing that makes me abandon this and not recommend it though is that this “free” game is very particular about the rewarding, and is extremely short of single player value. It is design to through you from the start in multi-player games (which is easier on the developers) and starve you from new cards unless you decide to put money on it. If you get too enthusiastic (as it’s indeed a well-polished game) you’ll probably buy some cards and that’s where Bioware money comes from.
I’m particularly burned with Bioware free to play business model from other experiences, so I may be reading too much from the time I played it, but it does look like a money trap.

If you are after a money trap that really pays off, try Magic Online, but if you are looking for free to play then Infinity Wars has a way better business model and an absurdly larger number of cards then Duel of Champions.

If you have the time, there’s no harm in trying it, but before putting money into it, look at what else is out there, because there’s plenty.

reviewText:
This game is a real shame.  It's not that this is a bad game, it's that the cash shop and playerbase make it totally not worth playing.  It has a campaign mode that helps, but becomes so difficult so quickly that you feel trapped in it too.  The game has a solid rules system, and lots of cool cards.  However, many of those cards can only be bought with cash.  What's worse, you can litterally purchase any card in the game, as many copies as you like and can afford.  This is a riddickulous option, because it allows players with money (I've found most of them to be spoiled little brats that have nothing better to do than drop hundreds of dollars online.) to buy the ultimate deck without needing to search thru booster pack or box sets.  This is probably, by far, the most abused part of the game.  I have seen countless players with a full deck of 60-100 card decks that are all rare cards, hand selected by a player with too much money and access.

This feature alone would be enough to turn many players off, but then you add in the annoying ♥♥♥ player base.  I've played collector card games for years, online and off. I'm talking magic, yu'gi'oh, vampire, might and magic, and many others.  I've never met a playerbase who seems to not give a ♥♥♥♥ about wasting your time.  I mean, it's epidemic within this game.  I'd say that about every 2 out of 3 players takes over a full minute to take a turn.  This is common even at the   beginning of a game, and you only have 1 point to spend.  ONE FREAKING POINT!  I mean, come on.  It should never take you that long to play out a simple round, and if you play the game, you'll see that there's absolutely no reason for it.  What's worse, I've actually ran into several players that will simply hold the game up when their loosing.  They do this so you'll just surrender or quit, and they don't get a loss on their record.  I've heard about competitive gameplay, but this goes way beyond that.

In the end, if you're looking for a really great, base defense, card game that will be mostly a waste of time because of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ players, then look no further.  If you just want to play in a game where being absolutely unfair and ruthless pays off, then this ones for you.  If you want a game that you can dominate with your mommy and daddy's money, and they have lots to waste, then hop on this train right here.

However, if you're looking for a fun card game to play online, you'll most likely be disappointed.  If you're looking for a fair game, where the cash shop doesn't rule everything, stay away.  Finally, if you're looking for an online game with a friendly community that doesn't consist of cheating ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and time wasting jerks, then you'll want to avoid this one.

reviewText: Well if it isn't pay to win, that fact eludes me. In the time I played my deck consisted of pretty crappy cards (even after I used the allowed gold coins from completing the tutorial etc.). In my one quick game my opponent had several premium cards and a deck consisting of many minions well above mine - in fact, he had a house card that allowed him to take any of his minions off the board on his turn, gain the turn cost of playing it, and then immediately play it again, so that essentially no unit of his could die, while of course mine could. And... back to the crappy deck that I had, there were no options in turns of spells etc. to counter this.\n\nOK, so no pvp for now, right? Well the only reason I played one quick game was because immediately progressing through the campaign required it. Well outside of the tutorial and your first 2 campaign runs, of incredibly low difficulty, low-and-behold the computer gains an incredible card deck and suddenly progression becomes near impossible. Good luck even progressing through the campaign.

reviewText:
When I first started playing this game I was immediately hooked and that was after playing Hearthstone. I pumped in about 100+ hours on this game. I really enjoyed all the different factions (mainly necromancer) and the levelling up system that seemed to give you a decent amount of cards.

However I ended up going back to Hearthstone for the rest of the year as this game fell into the background. I recently booted it up again, but was not interested in learning the dynamics once again and catching up on some of the new expansions.

It is definitely a fun and challenging game, but I would recommend looking into Hearthstone or another TCG game instead. A lot of the community has apparently left this game since it changed hands.

reviewText: Very good card game if you are into that sort of thing and want to lose the first about 5-10 matches before you can really start winning depending on the faction you start with and the cards you get from your first 4 packs the game decides to give you. I was excited to see the game with a campaign mode, that is, if you are into reading walls of text and playing the same match over and over again which you cant do until you earn the heroes from the other factions that is unless you want to do it for fun without rewards. You are pretty much forced to play quick match (pvp), and unless you pick a faction with three stars on one of the statistic areas you will lose almost every game until you can get enough packs to get another hero and make a new deck out of a different faction ( which you cant do unless you have a hero from the said faction). In the event you don't like the faction you chose, you can always opt to start over. Honestly, to me it felt like a magic the gathering style of game in the way it plays with a small hint of yu gi oh mixed in. Nothing really new or unique from this card game to others, but it is a more free based game in comparison, again if you are into that sort of thing.

reviewText:
There is no clearer reminder of how entertainment is a product than the Free-To-Play genre. Ultimately, that is this game's main failing--it is not a good product, even if it is a good game.

I actually started playing it before the single-player overhaul--back then, you could get Seals (the premium currency) from the campaign, and could also get them from daily log-in rewards.

Now, the only way to earn Seals without real money is a handful of acheivments, some of which are beyond the reach of average players (like winning 25 swiss tournaments--very high level play).

This means that anyone who chooses not to pay money is at a severe disadvantage. Okay, fine, nothing new for a F2P. The real problem comes from the fact that the game only allows purchases of randomized booster packs (buying singles takes another premium currency), and does not allow trading of your spare cards. You are only allowed to sell duplicates back to the game, and for a very tiny amount.

I have spent ~40 USD on this game, and I do not regret that purchase. For that amount of money, however, I really wish that the game gave me more resources. For the cost of a nearly new release, I received a bunch of cards that I couldn't trade and had no interest in playing. The large number of factions makes it harder for new players to build a focused deck, and the random nature and lack of packs means that building a good collection is a very frustrating, arduous process.

The game itself is fun, but I can't bring myself to recomend it to other people when it is such a frustrating product. At least IRL TCGs allow things like trading and purchasing singles, and the lack of these features really damages the experience.

This game was good, until you hit the higher ranked brackets where you get unbalanced decks just ruining everything. The problem with deck building is being a jack of all trades and a master of none works sometimes, not often. The other games where you go in highly specific with your deck and still get instagibbed with mass Geysers(Aoe spell that is really cheap) and perfectly timed damage spells. ♥♥♥♥ I hate how much time I wasted on this POS ♥♥♥♥ing game. Ubisoft is ♥♥♥♥. People usually just use heros of any faction as long as they have dark magic (the only magic that can destroy every creature without darkward for peanuts, roughly like 90% of the creatures get rekt). The RNG is horrendous, ♥♥♥♥ING horrendous. 59 card deck drawing 3 of the same cards consistently (80% of the time they are cards you really dont want until you set up your combo). Thats not luck, thats not RNG... thats ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T. Every game starting hand has at least 4 dead cards, ♥♥♥♥ing useless until at least turn 8. No ♥♥♥♥ing skill needed, at least not in standard league. Very rarely is there a game that goes back and forth nicely...its usually one sided from the get go. You need to follow the meta decks or you wont get anywhere, they just have a higher win chance from synergy...and there isnt enough synergy in general with cards...

Dont be a ♥♥♥♥ing queer ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mother ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥ like me and spend money on this huge waste of ♥♥♥♥ING time... reviewText:
The game sucks! I've lost every game after the tutorial. Why? Because my starting deck is high cost, low damage, low hp. You essentially have to grind to buy new card packs, even then you won't get enough decent cards to actually win a game.
Not only that, the game isn't consistent enough. I've seen players use a creature that only had 2 attack to destroy my very expensive 6 hp creep that I just played in the last turn, no spells or specialty cards, just outright died. There's no history log to review the card in question or what he did to destroy that creep.

Not noob friendly, the deck builder is terrible becuase you have to filter out all the cards that can't be used.
You can't even play the campaign becuase you need the other factions to complete the current mission to unlock the next mission, but you can't even do that because you have to grind in multiplayer to buy card packs that may or may not have enough cards to build another deck. There 8 factions but you only need 6 to unlock a mission.

Seems to be another pay 2 win game.

It's very frustrating game, suppose to be for casual, but losing every game is not relaxing.
♥♥♥♥ this game.

reviewText:
Greedy, greedy, greedy attempt to poach money. Don't touch unless you have have of extra money lying in your account. Even then, try Hearthstone for example. In this game you can only win if you pour lots of money into it, and most of the features (disenchanting unusable cards for example) open only by winning enough online games. And that is not going to happen with started deck.

You only get one hero (=faction) to play with, rest you can either buy on get by winning someone playing with that faction in online game (read above how that happens = money!). That means you can use approximately 1/6 of your booster cards, and you are not going to win without good cards. 2/0/2 minions don't defeat 4/3/6 minions. Also, there are so wast number of abilities that this is everything but beginner friendly game. Solo campaing could help, but in order to advance you have to beat online players (again =money!).

Simply put, don't touch!

reviewText:
I've played a ton of MTG in my life (physical and digital; still have all my old cards) and currently playing Hearthstone. I don't think this is a better game but it offers up something different with the strategy of hero abilities, point allocation, and cards playable by both sides. I wouldn't be surprised if many enjoyed this more than any other CCG. Recommended if you're a big card game fan or looking to get into a card game that offers something a little different. Strong mechanics, gorgeous art, and a sleak designs make this a game I will gladly dedicate mulitple hours to trying to unlock new cards and decks. Plus, you really can't beat the price.

Pro's
Really solid F2P CCG. It should be possible to get a portion of the cards unlocked and multiple decks without spending a dime.

Con's
Though it is F2P and I did say you could unlock a good bit without spending a dime. It is true that it won't be easy and you really have to be commited. I could see someone tiring of playing the same deck over and over for few pack of cards here and there.

Overall: 7 out of 10. (Score does take price point into account but if this was a $9.99 download, I imagine the score would be around the same I have it now)

Hard to get started.  But it can be a fun game.
The Daily Rewards is broken/buggy.  I Logged in for 6 days. but the 7th day it reset me back to day 1...

They also don't leave you any way to get premium currency without buying it (they used too.)

Hearthstone mops the floor with this game.

reviewText: large choice pool, but narrow success pool. Too many cards per expansion. Probably too many heroes overall. Difference in skill and decks between players creates a canyon too wide to keep new players attention. Time investment neccessary is enormous, and the economic investmentment is out of proportion for gathering revenue (I will blame European culture and mindset for business illiteracy). The foundation is there for a thriving business and a great CCG, but there is no physical property (ie cards) and the 2 investments above restrain a viable model.\n\nIf several thousand persons is what they want playing a game and receiving minimal revenue, then success is 100%. If they want hundred of thousands of players and tens of millions in $US-equivalant, then corrections need to be made across the board. You can't just cut into Magic with a fiat-card game.

reviewText:
newest review, I can no longer really suggest this game. While it is fun it is now VERY costly to get into and very limited to cash in order to begin being competative. Where as prior to the past 2 updates there were lots of ways to get seals (which cost real money) now there are no longer any ways except cash. That mixed with the diffrent mechanics in the newer sets makes it like trying to play MTG mixed across a bunch of diffrent series while you use a old starter deck. Fun game, ruined by their change in cash mechanics.
---------------------
Fun game, the only computer ccg that I have really found enjoyable. It feels much more like the old battletech card game then magic the gathering to me. The pace is some what similar to slower then magic, and no where near as fast as Hearthstone. The matches can go back and forth, a lot, giving strategy a nice amount of time to develop and really play out. It isn't nearly as much based on getting a one or two trick poney and just waiting till it pops out...you'll really have to go through stages of the battle.

Overall it is a great game. The interface is good in battle, outside of battle dealing with cards is ok.

The addition of wildcards is nice, the ability to basicly earn credits that you can use to buy specific cards you want (as opposed to randomly).

This isn't a pay to win game per say, it is rather balanced...that being said like any CCG, especialy one with 600+ cards, having access to multiple copies of a card or access to rare cards vastly increases your versitility. There are very few cards that just flat out are not fair/balanced, and in general the game can be very fun with little to minimal monitary investment.

If you do put money into it, the best deal is the steam Champions Pack 2, especialy if you can get it on sale. 70$ for 600 cards is far better then anything the duel server its self offers...and if steam will put the pack at -50% again...wish I had bought 2 of them.

reviewText: I was so excited when I first played, as the tutorial, card battle mechanics, and campaign mode seemed great. Obviously it is a MTG copy, but it has many differences to keep it fresh, such as more to manage than Mana and attacking specific cards. The choices in battle intrigued me. However, around the second hour in the game I realized I have to pay a lot to play, and the card decks just didn't seem organized. The solo game loses its guidance and I found myself grinding in the third hour to attempt to unlock stuff. The game forces you to do multiplayer as well. The UI with all its menus and locked sections were a drag. I would have preferred a limited demo with a clear explanation of what the full game offers than their current pay to play model.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: As a long term fan and player of Magic The Gathering this one has completely blind-sided me. I was not expecting to like it very much. Boy was I wrong. After installing this I played for an insane 18 hours straight and was totally hooked. But here's the important part, during that time I didn't spend a penny in cash and didn't NEED to. What you get to start with and the occasional booster every time you level up is more than enough to get you well on your way to being a good player. I dipped into the large and challenging campaign mode, I played 25 games of PVP with an 80% win rate, and I even held my own in ranked play with 3/4 wins. There is no time with this that you HAVE to pay and what you CAN pay for is very reasonable in cost. You can get a whole box set for a little over £12 or you can pay the price of a full game in a one-off that will get you the bulk of cards from every deck. The point is you don't need to.\nSo, the game itself, it's very different from magic, a lot faster and more intuitive, easier to learn but still with plenty of tactical depth. It's impossible to describe it fully in a short review but I HIGHLY recommend you give this one a go. 98%

reviewText:
I have vast experience with Magic the Gathering. It is still the best card game out there. No question.
IMO Hearthstone is fun but gets boring very fast.

At about 17h of gameplay MMDoC hooked me. The game mechanics flow well and the design is very good.
The combat system is VERY interesting and much deeper than in other games, which is definitely a big plus. I still get annoyed by the lack of player interaction (the fact i cannot play spells or abilities on the opponents turn)., but overall the game itself is very good.

I have however had a hard time figuring out what the timeline is for the games formats. No clue how often expansions will come out or how relevant older expansions will stay. This makes me very reluctant to spend any money.

That brings me to the next positive point: just by playing the campaigns or daily casual games you will be able to crack some packs (Ive spent 0, opened 15 packs until now).

I cannot comment on deckbuilding.
Community seems nice!

Apparently the game was sold to a new company and a draft mode is coming out but information is lacking.

reviewText:
I've played a ton of MTG in my life (physical and digital; still have all my old cards) and currently playing Hearthstone. I don't think this is a better game but it offers up something different with the strategy of hero abilities, point allocation, and cards playable by both sides. I wouldn't be surprised if many enjoyed this more than any other CCG. Recommended if you're a big card game fan or looking to get into a card game that offers something a little different. Strong mechanics, gorgeous art, and a sleak designs make this a game I will gladly dedicate mulitple hours to trying to unlock new cards and decks. Plus, you really can't beat the price.

Pro's
Really solid F2P CCG. It should be possible to get a portion of the cards unlocked and multiple decks without spending a dime.

Con's
Though it is F2P and I did say you could unlock a good bit without spending a dime. It is true that it won't be easy and you really have to be commited. I could see someone tiring of playing the same deck over and over for few pack of cards here and there.

Overall: 7 out of 10. (Score does take price point into account but if this was a $9.99 download, I imagine the score would be around the same I have it now)

reviewText:
This game needs a lot of work and I am on the fence about it.  If I was going to give it a rating I would say a 6 out of 10.  It is a free to play model and it really seems that you can get away with not spending anything and still succeed for a while if you are a veteran of the card game genre.  The game strategy is definitely solid and has some interesting elements, but there are pros and cons:

The good:

1. At its heart, the game seems like a solid strategy game and there are plenty of cards to mix things up a bit

2. The Swiss tournament system is one of the best I have seen in an online environment, but there are very few other options to choose from

3. Card art is good

4. The different decks and factions have a rich variety of play styles

5. Other than the lack of single player content, the game is getting a good amount of development work.  They even fixed an issue with Steam achievements when may publishers don't bother.

6. If you want to play and play and play, it seems that you can eventually get everything you need without spending one thin dime.


The Bad

1. There is no way to ramp up outside of playing other people.  With one deck worth of stuff it is a pretty monotonous way to grind to expanding your arsenal of cards and the campaigns/solo challenges are almost non existent.

2. The interface is definitely a bit raw.  It is clearly designed for mobile platforms but has a free to play java feel to it and it lacks the finesse that other titles in this genre have

3. No card or resource trading.  What you get is what you get.  This is only mitigated by the ability to forge cards out of sacrificing others or by getting special tokens from packs.

The Ugly

1. While the game has truly diverse play potential, you are locked to one deck unless you do a LOT of slogging through games to get enough cards and a new hero to build more.  Most of the cards in the game are keyed to a faction and CAN NOT be played by another faction under any circumstance, so every deck is a one color deck".  This is only mitigated by the fact that the one color tends to have enough diversity to be well rounded while still themed.  This means that when you do get enough coins to buy a pack and open it
date: 90% of the cards are unusable and I do mean unusable until you luck into a hero card from that faction to play them with.  Even then
recommended: it is unlikely you will have enough staple cards for alternate decks to do anything anyway.\n\n2. The pricing of the pay to play portion of the game is high in my opinion making getting a second faction starter even less attractive."
hoursPlayed: December 3, 2013
